journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Experimental investigation of metal organic frameworks characteristics for water adsorption chillers

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Birmingham, Birmingham Edgbaston, UK

author-notes.corresp: R Al-Dadah, School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Birmingham, Birmingham Edgbaston B15 2TT, UK. Email: R.K.Al-Dadah@bham.ac.uk

abstract.p: Adsorption cooling is a promising technology that can effectively utilise waste heat from many industrial processes for refrigeration and air conditioning. The choice of the adsorbent in this technology is vital to produce efficient and compact systems. Metal organic frameworks are new microporous materials with exceptionally high porosity and large surface area that can be used as adsorbents. This article experimentally investigates the characteristics of seven metal organic frameworks in terms of water adsorptivity compared to silica gel RD-2060. The adsorption characteristics were determined using an advanced gravimetric dynamic vapour sorption test facility. Results revealed that HKUST-1produced the highest water adsorption uptake with up to 95.7% increase compared to silica gel RD-2060 but showed deterioration in water adsorptivity with time. Throughout the temperature range tested, Fe-BTC has shown little hysteresis and produced up to 26.8% higher maximum water uptake value than silica gel RD-2060. These results highlight the potential of using certain metal organic frameworks materials to improve the efficiency of adsorption cooling systems; however, the thermal instability of some metal organic frameworks remains an issue that needs to be resolved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In adsorption applications, the choice of adsorption working pair is determined by the amount of heat that can be extracted from the evaporator per adsorption cycle. The heat extracted from the evaporator is proportional to the amount of vapour adsorbed and the latent heat of evaporation of the selected refrigerant. Therefore, the adsorbent uptake difference over a given cycle and latent heat of evaporation are the most effective parameters that influence the cycle cooling capacity and coefficient of performance.1 As a refrigerant, water has the advantages of high latent heat of evaporation, non-toxic and environmentally friendly refrigerant.2 Silica gel RD has been used as water adsorbent in many commercially available adsorption systems due to its low generation temperature and good adsorption uptake. However, the main problem of silica gel RD as adsorbent is that most of water adsorption occurs at high partial pressure. The partial pressure is the ratio between the supplied vapour pressure and the saturation vapour pressure corresponding to the operating temperature. For cooling applications, this means that the amount of water vapour adsorbed/desorbed in a cycle is only a small part of the total adsorption capacity of the silica gel RD-2060.3

Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are new microporous materials with exceptional high porosity, uniform pore size, well-defined molecular adsorption sites and large surface area (up to 5500 m2/g). MOFs have two main components: the organic linkers considered as organic secondary building unit, act as struts that bridge metal centres known as inorganic primary building units and act as joints in the resulting MOF architecture. The two main components are connected to each other by coordination bonds, together with other intermolecular interactions, to form a network with defined topology.4,5 Although MOFs have been originally designed and investigated for gaseous fuel storage such as hydrogen and methane,6,7 their use in water adsorption cooling is promising.8,9 Also, MOFs are less hydrophilic than silica gel RD-2060 or zeolite thus it can release more water vapour at the same partial pressure.3

There are limited data on MOFs water adsorption; therefore, this article experimentally investigates the water adsorption characteristics of seven different MOFs namely; HKUST-1 (copper based), Fe-BTC (iron based), MIL-53 (chromium based), MIL-53 (iron based), Birm-1, Birm-1-K and Birm-1-Li. HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC are manufactured by BASF, USA and commercially marketed by Sigma Aldrich UK as Basolite C300® and Basolite F300®, respectively. MIL-53 (chromium based) and MIL-53 (iron based) were designed and made in Warwick University.10 Three-dimensional porous material designated Birm-1, Birm-1-K and Birm-1-Li were designed and made in University of Birmingham, UK.11 These MOFs were initially tested at 36 ℃ to identify the best performing MOF materials in terms of maximum water uptake. HKUST-1and Fe-BTC have outperformed others, therefore their adsorption isotherms and kinetic performance were further investigated at temperatures ranging from 20 ℃ to 52 ℃ at increment of 8 K and vapour pressure ranging from 200 Pa to 10,000 Pa. Published models were then used for predicting the adsorption isotherms above 52 ℃ and evaluating the cyclic performance of these MOFs.

sec.title: Experimental test facility
sec.p:
There are two methods for measuring adsorption characteristics, namely, volumetric method and gravimetric method.12,13 In this investigation a dynamic vapour sorption (DVS) gravimetric analyser has been used to study the water adsorption characteristics (adsorption isotherms, kinetics and isosteres) of the selected MOFs (Figure 1). The DVS analyser has the advantages of directly measuring the adsorbent mass and preventing adsorbate vapour condensation on the moving balance parts. The adsorbent mass is measured using ultra-sensitive recording microbalance (Cahn D200), which has high long-term stability in microgram level as it adsorbs controlled concentrations of water or organic vapours. Dry nitrogen is used to purge the balance head and reaction chamber prior to sample loading. The purge flow is automatically controlled to prevent vapour condensation in the balance head and hence accurate uptake measurement is achieved. Mass flow controller is used to control the vapour pressure with a mixture of dry and saturated vapour gas. The test conditions were verified using optical vapour pressure sensor and RTD temperature probe very close to sample pan. The DVS analyser is automatically controlled by a dedicated PC microcomputer, which is interfaced with the microbalance. The accuracy of the DVS analyser microbalance is verified by using 100 mg standard calibration mass, where the expected accuracy of the tested sample is ±0.05 mg. Figure 1.
Schematic and pictorial diagram for the used DVS analyser.
DVS: dynamic vapour sorption.

The adsorption characteristics that affect the chiller performance are adsorption isotherms, isosteric heat of adsorption and adsorption kinetics. Samples of 10 mg each has been placed in the reaction chamber and were dried at fixed temperature of 55 ℃ until the condition of no change of mass, then allowed to undergo through adsorption/desorption testsat various partial pressures. The drying temperature was selected to be 5 K below the DVS analyser maximum operating temperature of 60 ℃. The sample mass is recorded every 4 s at different vapour pressure values to determine the adsorption kinetics. The sample isotherm is measured at each value of vapour pressure at the point of no change in adsorbent mass by measuring the adsorbent uptake. Here, it is worth pointing out that drying at higher temperatures than the one used in this work might lead to different results of the water uptake.

sec.title: MOF performance comparison
sec.p:
In order to identify best performing MOF materials in terms of maximum water uptake, the above-described testing procedure was initially used to test seven MOFs samples and one silica gel RD-2060 sample at constant temperature of 36 ℃. Figure 2 compares the maximum water vapour equilibrium uptake of the tested MOFs and silica gel RD-2060. From this figure, it is clear that HKUST-1 significantly outperform silica gel RD-2060 by up to 97.7% increase in the maximum water vapour uptake. Fe-BTC has shown modest improvement on the silica gel RD-2060 with up to 28.2% increase. Other MOFs were inferior to the silica gel RD-2060. Therefore, samples of HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC were tested to characterise their adsorption isotherms, cyclic and kinetic performance. This was carried out at temperatures ranging from 20 ℃ to 52 ℃ at increment of 8 K and vapour pressure ranging from 200 Pa to 10,000 Pa and the results were compared to those of the reference material silica gel RD-2060. Figure 3 presents scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and Table 1 presents the chemical formula, granular size, BET surface area and bulk density for these materials. Figure 2.
Comparison between the temporal experimental and predicted water vapour uptake.
Figure 3.
SEM images for: (a) Silica gel RD-2060, (b) HKUST-1, (c) Fe-BTC.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.
Table 1.
Physical properties of tested materials.
Property HKUST-1a Fe-BTCa Silica gel RD-2060
Chemical formula C18H6Cu3O12 C9H3FeO6 SiO2
Granules size 16 µm 5 µm 0.18-1 mm
BET surface area 1500–2100 m2/g 1300–1600 m2/g 840 m2/g
Bulk density 0.35 g/cm3 0.16–0.35 g/cm3 1 g/cm3
a
Information from Sigma Aldrich, UK.

sec.title: Silica gel RD-2060 performance
sec.p:
This section investigates the adsorption characteristics of silica gel RD-2060 in terms of adsorption isotherms and isosteric heat of adsorption to be used as a reference material and to validate the test procedure. Figure 4 shows the experimental results for adsorption isotherms of silica gel RD-2060 in terms of equilibrium uptake versus the vapour pressures at temperatures 20 ℃, 28 ℃, 36 ℃, 44 ℃ and 52 ℃ compared to the prediction of the Tóth equation (equation (1)). Figure 5 shows the deviation between the experimental results (shown in Figure 4) and those predicted by the Tóth equation to be within ±10%. Wang et al.12,13 demonstrated the capability of Tóth equation for fitting the experimental adsorption isotherms of silica gel RD-2060/water vapour at temperatures between 55 ℃ and 85 ℃ with average deviation of ±8.22%. Therefore, the Tóth equation was used to produce silica gel RD-2060 isotherms at temperatures of 60 ℃, 68 ℃, 76 ℃ and 84 ℃ (dotted lines in Figure 4). It is worth pointing out that the shaded rectangle on Figure 4 highlights the region of operating conditions of silica gel RD-2060/water adsorption chillers as reported by Wang et al.12 (1)w*=Koexp[ΔHads/ΔHadsRTRT]P{1+[(Ko/Koqmqm)exp(ΔHads/ΔHadsRTbedRTbed)P]t}(1/1tt) Figure 4.
Comparison between experimental and Toth isotherms.
Figure 5.
The deviation analysis of experimental and Toth isotherms.

Isosteric analysis is one of the key characteristics of adsorbents that need to be studied.14 Based on the experimentally measured isotherms, a family of adsorption isosteres is calculated and presented as straight lines in a ln(Pv) versus 1/Tads as shown in Figure 6. The slope of the presented isosteres (equation (2)) allows obtaining the isosteric heat of adsorption.15 The average calculated isosteric heat of adsorption of silica gel RD-2060 was found to be 2.43 × 106 J/kg, with deviation from published data ranging from 3.2% to 13.2% as shown in Table 2. (2)ln(Pv)=constant-ΔHs/RT Figure 6.
Isosteres of water/silica gel RD-2060.
Table 2.
Isosteric heat of adsorption.
Author ΔHs (J/kg) Deviation
Wang and Chua,16 and Wang et al.12 2.51×106 3.2%
Wang et al.13 2.69×106 9.7%
Akahira et al.17 and Uyun et al.18 2.80×106 13.2%

Adsorption rate can be measured using the gravimetric method for different adsorbent/adsorbate pairs.19–21 Figure 7 presents a typical measured isothermal temporal water vapour uptake for silica gel RD-2060 adsorbent sample at different vapour pressures at 36 ℃, including the drying period. In adsorption heat pumps and chillers the intraparticle mass transfer resistance dominates interparticle resistance.22 The key parameter of intraparticle mass transfer is the diffusion time constant, which is directly proportional to the surface diffusion, but inversely proportional to the adsorbent granules size. The rate of intraparticle mass transfer for different adsorbent/adsorbate pairs is normally measured using the gravimetric analyser and modelled with linear driving force model (LDF),19–21,23–26 (equations (3) and (4)). Figure 8 shows that the maximum deviation between the experimental results and those predicted by the LDF model are within ±20%. (3)w=w*-exp[-ksav·t+ln(w*-wt)] (4)ksav=(15Dso/Rp2)exp(-Ea/RT) Figure 7.
Temporal evaluation of the vapour pressure over sample and water vapour uptake (T = 36℃).
Figure 8.
Comparison between the temporal experimental and predicted water vapour uptake.

sec.title: HKUST-1 and FE-BTC water adsorption performance
sec.p: This section presents the characterisation process of HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC for water adsorption compared to silica gel RD-2060 in terms of the adsorption isotherms, adsorption kinetics and adsorption cycle analysis. The following sections (‘Adsorption isotherms’ and ‘Adsorption kinetics’) present the experimental results of adsorption isotherms and kinetics respectively at temperatures from 20 ℃ to 52 ℃ at intervals of 8 K and vapour pressure of 200–10,000 Pa. Section ‘Adsorption cycle analysis’ presents the ideal cycle analysis for adsorption cooling system based on typical operating conditions (condensation and adsorption at 32 ℃, evaporation at 5 ℃, desorption at 85 ℃). This analysis was based on the experimental measurements for temperatures below 52 ℃ and prediction technique based on published models for temperatures above 52 ℃. The heat of adsorption for HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC was calculated based on the method described in the previous section and found to be 2693 kJ/kg and 2632 kJ/kg, respectively. These values are within ±5% deviation from those reported by Henninger et al.1 for HKUST-1 and Kusgens et al.4 for iron-based MOFs.

sec.title: Adsorption isotherms
sec.p:
Figure 9 presents the experimental adsorption and desorption isotherms for silica gel RD-2060, HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC for the temperatures 20 ℃ and 52 ℃. It is shown that silica gel RD-2060, HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC isotherms behave as type-I, type-II and type-V adsorbents, respectively.27 For all tested vapour pressures, HKUST-1 adsorbs more water vapour than silica gel RD-2060 and Fe-BTC where the average maximum water vapour uptake value is 0.55 kgw/kgads which is 95.7% higher than that of the tested silica gel RD-2060. Figure 9 also shows that the Fe-BTC has low water adsorption at low vapour pressure and higher values at high vapour pressures. The average maximum equilibrium uptake value of Fe-BTC is 0.35 kgw/kgads, which is 26.8% higher than that of silica gel RD-2060. Based on these results, the maximum equilibrium uptake is highest for HKUST-1 followed by Fe-BTC and silica gel RD-2060. Figure 9 shows that HKUST-1 exhibit larger degree of hysteresis compared to silica gel RD-2060 and Fe-BTC. This is an indication of instability of this material, which will be investigated in section ‘Stability of HKUST-1.’ Figure 9.
Adsorption and desorption isotherms comparison for different adsorbents.

Regarding Fe-BTC isotherms, the measured values differ from those reported by Kusgens et al.,4 Jeremias et al.28 and Akiyama et al.29 both in terms of the maximum uptake value and the trend. Kusgens et al.4 investigated MIL100(Fe) (Fe3IIIO(H2O)2F.[H3(CO2)3]2.nH2O within=14.5]) synthesised based on procedure developed by Horcajada et al.30 using a solution of Fe powder, 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid and de-ionised water. The adsorption isotherms at temperatures of 298 K (25 ℃) and 323 K (50 ℃) as reported by Kusgenset et al.4 showed sharp increase in the water uptake. At 298 K, the sharp increase occurred at partial pressure of 0.2–0.3 while at 323 K, it occurred at 0.3–0.4 partial pressure. Jeremias et al.28 also investigated MIL-100(Fe) based on the same synthesis procedure reported by Horcajada et al.30 with a general structure of MIL-100 having the empirical formula 3D-{M3O(X)(H2O)2[BTC]2 · nH2O} where in their case M is Fe (Iron), X is F (Fluorine) and BTC is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate, trimesate. The water adsorption of the synthesised material was investigated at two temperatures namely 298 K (25 ℃) and 313 K (40 ℃). The sharp increase in water adsorption at partial pressure of 0.25 to 0.4 was also observed with maximum water uptake of 0.7 gw/gads. Akiyama et al.29 synthesised three new MIL-100 type MOFs based on the empirical structure of 3D-{M3O(X)(H2O)2 [BTC]2 · nH2O} but with M being Cr (Chromium), X being F (Fluorine), Cl (Chlorine) or SO4 (SulphurTetra oxide) and BTC is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate, trimesate). They investigated the water adsorptivity of the developed materials at 298 K (25 ℃) and observed the sharp increase in water uptake at partial pressure of 0.2 to 0.3 with maximum uptake of 0.7 gw/gads. The Fe-BTC used in this investigation is the commercially available material from Sigma Aldrich labelled as Basolite – F300 with chemical formula C9H3FeO6Fe. This differs from other Fe-based MOFs reported by Akiyama et al.29 where Chromium is used instead of Iron and Fluoride acid is used in the synthesis. It also differs from those synthesised by Kusgens et al.4 and Jeremias et al.28 where F (Flourine) is apparent in the chemical formula. This difference in chemical formula/synthesis process may explain the difference in water uptake performance.

sec.title: Adsorption kinetics
sec.p:
The adsorption kinetics is an essential factor that should be considered during comparison between different adsorption pairs.21 It determines the rate at which the adsorbent material adsorbs/desorbs the refrigerant. Figure 10 presents the time variation of the measured water uptake of the tested adsorbents at different temperatures and vapour partial pressure of 0.1. It is clear that HKUST-1 shows the maximum adsorption rate followed by silica gel RD-2060 and Fe-BTC except in the first few seconds. The fast adsorption rate of HKUST-1/water pair implies that short adsorption/desorption cycle time can be used in the development of waste heat driven adsorption cooling systems.31 Figure 10.
Adsorption kinetics comparison for silica gel RD-2060, HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC.

sec.title: Adsorption cycle analysis
sec.p: Many adsorption isotherms models have been reported in the literature including Dubinin-Astakhov (D-A), Sips, Tóth, Freundlich, Langmuir and Temkin and Hill-de Boer.32–35 The selection of a suitable model to fit the experimental data depends on the adsorption isotherm profile. With the limitation of the DVS analyser used where the maximum operating temperature is 60 ℃, the adsorption isotherms for Fe-BTC and HKUST-1 at temperatures above 52 ℃ were determined using Sips and Langmuir models.36,37

Figure 11 shows the experimental data for HKUST-1 fitted using Langmuir’s equation with 95% confidence and prediction levels. The calculated values of coefficients W∞ and b (in equation (6)) are found to be 0.64 and 8.33, respectively with R2 value of 0.98. Figure 12 shows the experimental data for Fe-BTC fitted using Sip’s equation with 95% confidence and prediction levels. The calculated values of coefficients W∞, b and n (in equation (7)) are 0.38, 2.75 and 3.63 respectively with R2 value of 0.98. W∞ presents the maximum adsorption capacity in kgw/kgads and the deviation between the experimental and predicted values are 3.2% and 2.7% for HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC, respectively. It is interesting to point out here, the S shape profile of the Sip’s model fits the experimental data of the Fe-BTC. Therefore, equations (6) and (7) were used to predict the adsorption isotherms of HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC at temperatures above 52 ℃. (6)w*=⌊W∞[b·(Psat,Tref/Psat,Tads) (1+b·(Psat,Tref/Psat,Tads))]⌋ (7)w*=W∞[(b·Psat,Tref/Psat,Tads)n (1+(b·Psat,Tref/Psat,Tads)n)] Figure 11.
HKUST-1 experimental isotherms fitting using Langmuir’s equation.
Figure 12.
Fe-BTC experimental isotherms fitting using Sip’s equation.

The thermodynamic relation between pressures, adsorption temperatures and water vapour concentration is presented by the P-T-W (pressure–temperature–concentration) diagram where the concentration is defined as the mass of water vapour per unit mass of dry adsorbent. Using the above procedure, Figure 13 presents the P-T-W diagram for HKUST-1, Fe-BTC and silica gel RD-2060 with the ideal adsorption cooling cycle superimposed. For all the materials tested, the ideal adsorption cooling cycle consists of adsorption and condensation at 32 ℃, desorption at 85 ℃ and evaporation at 5 ℃ as typically used in chilled water systems. Results show that the values of the water vapour concentration at the end of desorption–adsorption are 0.22–0.42 kgw/kgads, 0.05–0.10 kgw/kgads and 0.06–0.13 kgw/kgads for HKUST-1, Fe-BTC and silica gel RD-2060, respectively. It is clear that HKUST-1 has the highest values of water vapour concentration at the end of desorption–adsorption processes indicating higher rates of refrigerant circulation which leads to higher cooling capacities. Figure 13.
P-T-W diagram for different adsorption pair with ideal cycle superimposed.
P-T-W: pressure–temperature–concentration.

Figure 14 shows the adsorption cooling cycle for HKUST-1 and Fe-BTC (1-2-3-4-1) compared to that of silica gel RD-2060 (1s-2s-3s-4s-1s). From Figure 14(a), the values of the water uptake difference (W3-W1) for HKUST-1 material is 0.20 kgw/kgads and that of silica gel RD-2060 (W3s-W1s) is 0.07 kgw/kgads which yields 185.7% enhancement in the water uptake difference. Following the same analysis for the Fe-BTC, Figure 14(b) shows that the water uptake difference is significantly lower than that of silica gel RD-2060 by up to 28%. This makes this tested type of Fe-BTC not suitable for chilled water systems where evaporating temperature of 5 ℃ is needed. However, at vapour pressure higher than 1.2 kPa (corresponding to evaporation temperature of 10 ℃), the water uptake of Fe-BTC becomes higher than that of silica gel RD-2060 and hence can produce higher refrigerant circulation rate as shown in Figure 14(c). Therefore it is useful here to highlight that the thermal stability and its cycle analysis using evaporating temperature of 12 ℃ demonstrate the potential of Fe-BTC to be used as an upper cycle for cascade cooling applications. Figure 14.
Isotherms comparison with ideal cycle superimposed.

sec.title: Stability of HKUST-1
sec.p:
In an adsorption cooling system, the adsorbent material undergoes large number of adsorption/desorption cycles which necessitates that the adsorbents have stable adsorptivity performance with time. Figure 15 shows the adsorption isotherms of HKUST-1 at four consecutive cycles with every isotherm obtained from a cycle of drying, adsorption and desorption at 36 ℃. The figure shows a marked loss of performance in terms of the water uptake at each repeated cycle, which highlights the thermal instability of HKUST-1 MOF towards water vapour. Figure 15.
HKUST isotherms degradation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Recently MOFs have attracted extensive research interest for gaseous fuel storage, gas separation and carbon dioxide capturebut limited interest in applications based on water adsorption such as vapour adsorption cooling systems. HKUST-1, Fe-BTC, MIL-53-Cr, MIL-53-Fe, Birm-1, Birm-1-K and Birm-1-Li were tested using dynamic vapour sorption analyser for water adsorption performance. Compared to silica gel RD-2060, results regarding water vapour uptake showed that HKUST-1 has significant improvement of up to 95.7%, Fe-BTC has modest improvement with up to 26.8% while others were inferior to the silica gel RD-2060.

Regarding cycle analysis the HKUST-1/water pair has the best adsorption characteristics with 185.7% increase in the water vapour uptake difference compared to silica gel RD-2060 at evaporating temperature of 5 ℃. This favourable trend is persistent throughout the investigatedtemperature range. As for the tested Fe-BTC, it has shown an inferior performance compared to that of silica gel RD-2060 with 28% reduction in the water vapour uptake difference in the cycle with evaporating temperature of 5 ℃. It is important here to point out that this trend is reversed for evaporating temperatures above 10 ℃ (vapour pressure of 1.2 kPa) at the same adsorption, condensation and desorption temperatures. The significance of this finding implies that the tested Fe-BTC can be used in cascade cooling applications where the evaporation temperature can be higher than 12 ℃, which highlights its potential.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors wish to thank Weatherite Holdings Ltd and the Engineering and Physical Science Research Council (EPSRC) for sponsoring the project. Also thanks are due to Dr. Rachel Brisdon for providing the access to the DVS analyser, Professor Richard Walton of Warwick University for providing MIL-53-CrandMIL-53-Fe and Dr. Paul Anderson of the school of Chemistry in the University of Birmingham for supplying Birm-1, Birm-1-K and Birm-1-Li.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by EPSRC industrial case award No. 08001389 and Weatherite Holdings.
